channel.title: World : NPR
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: More survivors are found 3 days after China building collapse
item.description: Police have arrested nine people, including the building owner, on suspicion of ignoring building codes or committing other violations.
item.content:encoded:
Police have arrested nine people, including the building owner, on suspicion of ignoring building codes or committing other violations.

(Image credit: Chen Zeguo/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Biden meets with parents of abducted journalist Austin Tice
item.description: President Biden met with the parents of American journalist Austin Tice, who was abducted in Syria nearly 10 years ago. He has not been heard from since. Syria has never acknowledged holding him.
item.content:encoded:
President Biden met with the parents of American journalist Austin Tice, who was abducted in Syria nearly 10 years ago. He has not been heard from since. Syria has never acknowledged holding him.

(Image credit: Bilal Hussein/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (May 2)
item.description: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

(Image credit: Chris McGrath/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: The war in Ukraine has the cost of bread skyrocketing in places like the Middle East
item.description: The war in Ukraine has exacerbated inflation in the Middle East, where countries rely on Russia and Ukraine for imported wheat.
item.content:encoded: The war in Ukraine has exacerbated inflation in the Middle East, where countries rely on Russia and Ukraine for imported wheat.
item.dc:creator: Peter Granitz

item.title: Why it took nearly 100 years for umami to be globally accepted as a distinct flavor
item.description: A Japanese chemist identified umami in the early 1900s, but it took a century for his work to be translated into English. NPR's Short Wave podcast looked into why it took so long to be recognized.
item.content:encoded: A Japanese chemist identified umami in the early 1900s, but it took a century for his work to be translated into English. NPR's Short Wave podcast looked into why it took so long to be recognized.
item.dc:creator: Chloee Weiner

item.title: Civilians and soldiers remain trapped in a Mariupol steel plant
item.description: More civilians are being evacuated Monday from a steel facility in Mariupol, Ukraine. But thousands of soldiers remain, many of whom are injured and have been holed up for weeks.
item.content:encoded: More civilians are being evacuated Monday from a steel facility in Mariupol, Ukraine. But thousands of soldiers remain, many of whom are injured and have been holed up for weeks.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Kakissis

item.title: Israel slams Russia's foreign minister for comparing Zelenskyy to Hitler
item.description: Israeli officials are calling for an apology after Sergey Lavrov said the Hitler "had Jewish origins." It's the strongest condemnation of Russia by Israel since the war in Ukraine began in February.
item.content:encoded:
Israeli officials are calling for an apology after Sergey Lavrov said the Hitler "had Jewish origins." It's the strongest condemnation of Russia by Israel since the war in Ukraine began in February.

(Image credit: Alexander Zemlianichenki/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Angelina Jolie met with refugees and volunteers during a surprise visit to Lviv
item.description: The actress and U.N. Special Envoy for refugees spoke with recent evacuees arriving by train in the western Ukraine city, as well as children being treated for injuries from a recent Russian attack.
item.content:encoded:
The actress and U.N. Special Envoy for refugees spoke with recent evacuees arriving by train in the western Ukraine city, as well as children being treated for injuries from a recent Russian attack.

(Image credit: Eduard Tomilchenko/AP)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Ukraine is the focus, but Russian troops are in several ex-Soviet republics
item.description: Russian forces have been active in multiple former Soviet republics this year, a reflection of Russian leader Vladimir Putin's desire to maintain a 'sphere of influence' beyond Russia's borders.
item.content:encoded:
Russian forces have been active in multiple former Soviet republics this year, a reflection of Russian leader Vladimir Putin's desire to maintain a 'sphere of influence' beyond Russia's borders.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Estonia hosts NATO-led cyber war games, with one eye on Russia
item.description: Estonia is host to one of the world's largest annual interactive cybersecurity drills. Russia is always considered the main threat, but this year, the war in Ukraine has only added to the stakes.
item.content:encoded:
Estonia is host to one of the world's largest annual interactive cybersecurity drills. Russia is always considered the main threat, but this year, the war in Ukraine has only added to the stakes.

(Image credit: Nora Lorek for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Jenna McLaughlin

item.title: Sydney man gets 12 years for murdering gay American in 1988
item.description: The death of mathematician Scott Johnson was initially called a suicide, but his family pressed for further investigation.
item.content:encoded:
The death of mathematician Scott Johnson was initially called a suicide, but his family pressed for further investigation.

(Image credit: Rick Rycroft/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Mazel Tov Cocktail Party: Take an ounce of hip hop, dash of polka, then square dance
item.description: Finding a thriving dance culture in the Adirondacks Mountains inspired the band to take its sound in an unexpected direction.
item.content:encoded:
Finding a thriving dance culture in the Adirondacks Mountains inspired the band to take its sound in an unexpected direction.

(Image credit: Laura Carbone/Kathleen Tagg)
item.dc:creator: Jon Kalish

item.title: New Zealand welcomes back tourists as it eases pandemic rules
item.description: New Zealand welcomed tourists from the U.S., Canada, Britain, Japan and more than 50 other countries for the first time in more than two years.
item.content:encoded:
New Zealand welcomed tourists from the U.S., Canada, Britain, Japan and more than 50 other countries for the first time in more than two years.

(Image credit: Jed Bradley/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Workers around the world mark May Day with rallies for better working conditions
item.description: From New York City to Turkey, activists and workers seized this International Workers' Day as a moment to push for greater worker protections and changes to immigration policies.
item.content:encoded:
From New York City to Turkey, activists and workers seized this International Workers' Day as a moment to push for greater worker protections and changes to immigration policies.

(Image credit: Stephanie Keith/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Family of 'Hotel Rwanda' hero sues Rwandan government for kidnapping and torture
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina saved more than 1,200 people during the 1994 Rwandan genocide. The Rwandan government convicted him of terrorism in a trial that human rights groups call a sham.
item.content:encoded:
Paul Rusesabagina saved more than 1,200 people during the 1994 Rwandan genocide. The Rwandan government convicted him of terrorism in a trial that human rights groups call a sham.

(Image credit: Timothy Hiatt/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Dustin Jones
